https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/171261,2016,"International migration: Theories, types, trends, and policies",English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,"['dr. B. Martinovic', 'dr. W.H. Poppe']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The aim of the course is to explain and examine the processes underlying     contemporary     international     migration     from     a     theory-guided     and     comparative     approach.     Having     completed     the     course     students     should     be     familiar     with     the     key     questions     and     theories     related     to     the     research     field     of     international     migration,     be     able     to     derive     testable     predictions     at     macro,     micro     and     meso     levels     of     explanation     and     be     able     to     critically     evaluate     theories,     research     strategies     and     findings     on     international     migration.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: The course deals with the main trends, theories and findings of international migration. Examples of questions that will be discussed in the course are: What is international migration? Which types and trends of migration are present in Western countries? What causes migration, and which factors cause its continuation or change? Which factors affect the various immigration control policies? What are the determinants of attitudes towards immigration policies? What are the main reasons of return migration? Throughout the course, theoretical approaches and empirical studies from different disciplinary traditions are discussed (sociology, economics, demography, psychology), explaining migration at micro-, meso-, and macro-levels of analysis. The emphasis of the course is on theory-driven, comparative research examples, strategies and findings. In addition, current controversies in the field of migration studies will be discussed.</body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/175908,2016,International research project Suriname,Dutch,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,['dr. M.J. van der Meulen'],,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
De student kan na het afronden van deze cursus en het voltooien van het onderzoeksproject:

column2: • laten zien over kennis en inzicht te beschikken in Bestuurs- en Organisatiewetenschappelijke vraagstukken op het gebied van publieke waardecreatie en maatschappelijke zelforganisatie in de context van Suriname;

• laten zien te beschikken over kennis van en inzicht in de culturele diversiteit van een land (Suriname) mede op basis van een verblijf van meerdere weken, het verrichten van onderzoek en samenwerken in dat land;

• abstracte theoretische kernvragen omvormen tot concrete onderzoeksprojecten binnen het bredere onderzoeksthema en de daarvoor benodigde abstracte theoretische concepten relevant maken voor het gezamenlijk onderzoeksproject;
• een kwalitatief onderzoek uitvoeren waarbij de data vergaard wordt in het buitenland (Suriname) en reflecteren op de betekenis van cultuurverschillen bij het interpreteren van deze data;
• intensief samenwerken in een duo en als onderdeel van een grotere groep met een gemeenschappelijk onderzoeksdoel en reflecteren op de daarvoor benodigde vaardigheden en verantwoordelijkheid;
• samenwerken met studenten vanuit een andere culturele context en reflecteren op de daarbij benodigde vaardigheden;
• zijn bevindingen en analyses (op samenhangende wijze) presenteren als onderzoeksartikel dat kan worden gepubliceerd in een gezamenlijke bundel.
• zijn bevindingen en analyses presenteren tijdens een symposium en deze duidelijk maken aan een publiek dat niet heeft deelgenomen aan het onderzoeksproject;
• op een overkoepelend niveau meewerken aan gemeenschappelijke conclusies ten behoeve van een bundel en een symposium.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Het Research Project is een tweejaarlijks uniek en grensoverschrijdend project van de studie Bestuurs- en Organisatiewetenschap in samenwerking met studievereniging Perikles. Een groep studenten reist af naar een ander land. Hier doen zij in duo’s onderzoek naar actuele bestuurskundige of sociaalmaatschappelijke vraagstukken in een andere cultuur. Het project heeft een tijdsspanne van ongeveer één jaar: van de start van een nieuw Research Project met de vorming van een nieuwe groep deelnemers tot het afsluitende symposium ongeveer een jaar later. Het doel van het project is om een groep van geselecteerde studenten kennis te laten maken met het doen van een kwalitatief empirisch onderzoek binnen een andere, vreemde context dan die zij in Nederland gewend zijn. Deelname aan het Research Project door derdejaars bachelor studenten Bestuurs- en Organisatiewetenschap staat gelijk aan een voltijdskeuzevak (15 ECTS).
Een commissie van acht studenten houdt zich bezig met de organisatie van het Research Project.

In het najaar van 2016 reizen de deelnemers en commissie voor een nieuwe editie van het RP af naar Suriname. In de hoofdstad van Suriname, Paramaribo gaan ze in duo’s onderzoek doen in samenwerking met studenten van Public Administration van Anton de Kom Universiteit. Het hoofdthema is: de zoektocht naar de kracht van de Surinaamse samenleving. Met als overkoepelende vraag hoe men in Surinaamse publieke waardecreatie tracht te bewerkstelligen doormiddel van maatschappelijke zelforganisatie.

De omgeving van het publieke domein in Nederland is de afgelopen decennia aan veranderingen onderhevig. Doordat de samenleving is veranderd voldoen tegenwoordig oude organisatievormen en werkwijzen niet langer als oplossing van complexe vraagstukken. Na de stroming New Public Management is er meer en meer een trend te zien naar Public Value Management (Stoker, 2006). Public Value Management kan gezien worden als de waarde die een organisatie en/of verzameling van mensen met een activiteit of dienst toevoegt aan de maatschappij, op zowel korte als lange termijn. Het creëren van publieke waarde is voor publieke organisaties niet altijd even makkelijk. In de breedste zin van het woord: hoe creëer je eigenlijk publieke waarde? Wat verstaan we onder publieke waarde? Bovendien hoe maak je resultaten meetbaar en hoe weet je waar precies moet worden bijgestuurd? Wat is  New Public Value management in een ander land dan Nederland? Dit onderzoek kan zowel bijdragen aan kennis over publieke waarde in het algemeen,  als de vraag hoe publieke waarde gecreëerd kan worden binnen een (buitenlandse) onbekende complexe omgeving.

In november 2015 waren Suriname en Nederland 40 jaar onafhankelijk, naast de Nederlandse taal is er vanuit een historisch perspectief nog steeds een speciale band tussen beide landen. Binnen Suriname bestaat een enorme verscheidenheid aan verschillende bevolkingsgroepen; culturen en talen die allen naast elkaar leven. Deze culturele diversiteit maakt Suriname een bijzonder land om onderzoek binnen te verrichten. Ook is Suriname een land in ontwikkeling, met name op sociaalmaatschappelijk vlak: vele projecten worden opgezet vanuit het maatschappelijk middenveld met als doel de kwaliteit van leven in Suriname naar een hoger niveau te tillen. Dit komt door een Surinaamse regering welke te kampen heeft met vele doelmatigheid en efficiëntie problemen. Dit brengt veel economische -en (sociale) maatschappelijke vraagstukken met zich mee. Veel complexe maatschappelijke vraagstukken binnen het land worden mondjesmaat door de regering opgepakt en blijven hierdoor voortleven. De gevolgen van een wereldwijde economische crisis werken niet mee aan een eventuele verbetering van de status quo. Interessant is om te kijken of en hoe de Surinaamse bevolking hier mee omgaat. Hier komt maatschappelijke zelforganisatie naar voren. Samenwerkingsverbanden tussen organisaties, groepen mensen en/of individuen die vanuit de markt en gemeenschap (community), samenwerken om bepaalde sociaal-maatschappelijke vraagstukken/ problemen op te lossen (publieke waarde creëren). Kortom initiatieven vanuit de samenleving van burgers, organisaties en/of private partijen die bijdragen aan verbetering van het sociaalmaatschappelijke leven.

Het tijdpad is als volgt. In april 2016 wordt er een groep van twintig studenten geselecteerd. In periode 4 van het collegejaar 2015-2016 en in periode 1 van het collegejaar 2016-2017 volgen zij wekelijks onderwijsbijeenkomsten waarin zij voorbereid worden op het onderzoek. Deze bijeenkomsten gaan in op het thema, de Surinaamse context en het doen van onderzoek. Devoorbereiding wordt afgerond met 2 opdrachten: een schrijfopdracht en een onderzoeksvoorstel. Daarna reist de groep voor zes weken af naar Suriname om hier onderzoek te doen, in samenwerking met de studenten van de Anton de Kom Universiteit. Bij terugkomst in Nederland worden de onderzoeken uitgewerkt in wetenschappelijke artikelen die door de commissie samengevoegd worden in een onderzoeksbundel. Deze bundel wordt uitgebracht op een symposium in april 2017 waar alle duo’s ook hun onderzoek presenteren. Studenten sluiten het Research Project niet alleen af met een onderzoeksartikel, maar ook met een individueel reflectieverslag.
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174171,2016,Internet Social Media and Networks,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. R. Corten'],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • the student is familiar with core concepts from social network theory;
• the student is familiar with some important research methods for the analysis of social networks;
• the student is familiar with the most important research questions, theories, and social research findings in the field of the internet and social media;
• the student is able to translate specific contemporary social problems and policy issues into relevant research questions in the field of the internet and social media;
• the student is able to use specialized software for social network analysis and visualization for basic analyses;
• the student is familiar with common data collection methods in the field of online social interaction.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column5: The internet plays an increasingly important role in modern societies. More and more, social interaction, between individual people, but also between consumers and producers, and citizens and the government, takes place online. These developments imply many new sociological and societal questions, but also provide opportunities for new research and new policies. For example, does the emergence of the internet hinder or promote social cohesion in the sense of intergroup contact? Does internet usage foster loneliness? What is the impact of formal and informal online social networks on the effectivity of organizations?  What is the role of the internet in the self-organizing capacity of political and social movements?

Some of these questions relate to long-standing sociological questions and theories for which the internet provides new and exciting testing grounds; other questions require new theory altogether.In any case, the richness of digital data generated by online social interaction provides unprecedented opportunities for social scientists to study new and old research questions in innovative ways, and thereby to contribute to the solution of important social problems.

It turns out that many of these questions can be fruitfully studied from the perspective of social network analysis. In this course, students learn how to apply theories and methods from social network analysis to questions about the internet and social media, in the context of contemporary social problems. Methods of data collection in online social contexts, use of specialized software, and ethical issues will also be discussed.
Final Goals
Completing the Masters programme in Sociology: contemporary social problems provides students with:
Knowledge and understanding in the area of defining problems, theories, research and policy:
1a.       Important theories and models for examination of current social issues;
specific knowledge and understanding in relation to one of the tracks on offer, specifically:
o   Health, Policy and Organisations track: key concepts from the governance & network theory in relation to health issues;
o   Crime and Safety track: key concepts in criminology in relation to public security issues;
o   Internet, Social Media and Networking track: key concepts from social network theory in relation to social issues.
Application of knowledge and understanding.
2a        Analyse complex questions from a sociological/interdisciplinary/comparative theoretical perspective and relate these to scientific and social debates.
2b        Translate/apply new and previously acquired socio-scientific knowledge to current social issues.
2c        Operationalise theoretical, methodological and practically-oriented understanding in a feasible research proposal.
2e        Carry out independent research, draw conclusions from it in written and spoken form in a clear, straightforward manner to present to an audience of specialists and non-specialists.
2f         Create a link between scientific knowledge, research questions and practical issues.
2g        Provide a client with responsible advice on policy or organisation.
Form judgements about scientific­, societal and ethical aspects.

3a        Reflect on developments and discussions in science and society with regard to current social issues, on the basis of well-founded theoretical, analytical, methodological and practice-oriented considerations.
3b        Critically reflect upon information they have gathered themselves on current social issues based on theoretical, methodological, practice-oriented and social considerations.
3c        Adopt an honest and critical position in relation to research plans and results.
3e        Think critically about the professional ethics of people working in sociology within a wide social context.
Communication.
4a        Report, independently and in an academically sound way, on their own activities and present clear recommendations to interested parties both verbally and in writing.
4c         Report the results of their own research, or advice, to clients or others working in the field verbally and in writing in a clear and structured manner.
Learning skills.
5b        Reflect upon professional ethical issues within their future professional field.
5c        Deal with ethical aspects in a well-considered manner as an academic professional.
5e        Work independently in professional practice.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The topic could be theoretical or practical, could include fieldwork and/or lab-work and/or computer-based simulation/modelling. The various options include: a work placement in a company or government organisation working in Earth Sciences or participating in university research. In consultation with the proposed supervisors - one internal supervisor (teacher) and one external supervisor (from the organisation offering the training), a traineeship proposal should be formulated. This should also contain details of credits involved (ECTS), time-planning, deliverables (reports/presentations), confidentiality aspects etc. to avoid last-minute surprises on all sides. The traineeship request form and proposal MUST be submitted for PRIOR approval to, first, the internal supervisor, and then the traineeship coordinator of the relevant MSc-ES programme who will pass it on to the board of examiners for final approval. If the traineeship is also to be used for the mandatory graduation research, the traineeship proposal should also be submitted to the coordinator of the relevant MSc-ES programme for PRIOR approval.

According to the examination rules and regulations with regards to the MSc programmes Hydrology and Physical Geography, a student should first hand in a first version of his/her MSc graduation thesis before he/she is allowed to start off with a traineeship.
More information and required forms are available on website: enter the page for your master programme and look for “internship”.

body { font-size: 9pt; writing scripts to collect, manage and analyze text.

column3: The internship enables students to acquire hands-on experience with linguistics research in an ongoing project headed by a senior researcher. The aim is to practice research, academic and communicative skills the students have been equipped with during the RMA programme, and to prepare them for carrying out their own research in the RM thesis. Therefore, the internship follows (most of) the electives, and precedes the thesis. The internship may but need not be directly connected to the student’s thesis, by providing, for instance, a pilot experiment or preliminary data/corpus collection that will be improved and further worked out/analyzed in the thesis or a critical evaluation of theoretical background.      </body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

A substantial component involves writing scripts (simple programs) in the Python programming language.  We will learn how to use scripts to manage and analyze texts (“corpus analysis”), carry out searches that go far beyond what you can do with a standard web form, count words and constructions, create randomized experimental stimuli, etc.
Students will become familiar with different types of digital language resources, and some of their uses in theoretical or experimental research.
The skills learned in this course can be applied to employment outside academia, in the domain of natural language processing. The programming component has even broader utility.

Together with the thesis, the research master internship constitutes the individual trajectory of the student. The exact activities/tasks, mode of working, schedule and expected outcomes may vary across individual internship projects, but they are all always agreed upon prior to the beginning of the internship and spelled-out in the written Trainee Agreement form. The Trainee Agreement form must be signed by the internal supervisors, the student and (if applicable) the external supervisor to be valid. Trainees can participate in internships that take place i) in-house, ii) at another researh institution in the Netherlands, or iii) abroad. Students are responsible for finding their own supervisor, but are strongly encouraged to consult with the RMA tutor on their choice. In all cases the trainee must have an internal (in-house) supervisor, who is responsible for filing the results in Osiris. All internships, even those predominantly oriented towards application and valorization must have a clearly defined component of fundamental/basic research in it.  All internship projects must have two final deliverables:  a) Research Paper – a paper presenting the research question(s), relevance, theoretical framework, methodology, result(s), outcome(s), and conclusion(s) of the research project and b) Reflection Report -  a short report following the internship (2 A4 pages), reflecting upon the suitability and desirability of the research environment the internship took place in, be it for theoretical, experimental, or applied work. Both are submitted to the local internship supervisor, who bases the final grade on their combined content (in conjunction with a second, possibly external supervisor when applicable). The Reflection Report is also submitted to the RMA tutor and archived accordingly.
Orientation on a future research oriented career in academia or outside of academia.</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>An internship offers students the opportunity to gain experience of the world beyond academia. In certain fields, internships are essential for students proceeding to graduate studies, and they are highly recommended to all who wish to develop their practical as well as their theoretical skills beyond academia. Students may only undertake one internship as part of their UCU programme. A requirement of such an internship is that it allows the intern to reflect upon the work carried out within their academic program at UCU. This connection should be clearly outlined in the internship proposal.

Students carry out agreed tasks within an organisation such as a company, an NGO, or any other organisation they wish to work for. The nature of the tasks may vary according to the host organisation’s needs, as long as there is a possibility for the student to reflect on the work carried out, since after completion of the internship the student must write a report that connects the practical work undertaken with his or her academic program. Depending on the nature of the task, the student either includes this reflection in their final report, or as an appendix to the report.
An internship counts as a level 2 course. It consists of at least five weeks fulltime practical experience in an (external) organisation. It is taken as a P/F course, and counts as an elective.

A Departmental Internship that is academic in nature may count towards a student's major, is academically supervised, and is graded. Within the intership proposal procedure, a student can indicate if there is an academic component or not, after which the role of the internship in the curriculum will be apporved by the UCU coordinator or fellow. An Academic Intership is coded within the Department: UCHUMINT21, UCSCIINT21, or UCSSCINT21

Examples of academic internship activities: museum internships associated with cultural heritage (CHIP), compiling research literature, conducting archival research, writing computer scripts, processing data for a publication, etc.

A student wishing to do an internship must locate a host institution and local supervisor (to guide the work undertaken). Local sources such as fellows, the careers advisory officer, teachers and tutors may be consulted to offer advice on institutions and supervisors, but UCU cannot be asked to mediate formally in the process of finding an internship.

The task of the UCU coordinator is: a) guide and advise the student if necessary b) approve the grade and c) make sure the student uploads an electronic version of the report to the HandIn function of the Internship workspace.

Any student is at liberty to make their own arrangements; there is no GPA limit. Students may also compete for a limited number of internships arranged by UCU as part of specific programs. These may have specific selection criteria and/or prerequisites.

The consent of the UCU Career DEvelopment Officer is required for an internship to count as part of the student’s UCU curriculum. This consent should be given before the internship starts.  For this purpose, an internship agreement form should be signed by all parties involved. This agreement specifies the student’s tasks, prerequisites, supervision meetings, and the date the report will be handed in, as well as any physical, liability and financial constraints. As an appendix to the agreement, an internship proposal should be present,, specifying the content of the work.
Forms for the internship proposal and for the internship agreement can be found on the UCU's student website: http://students.uu.nl/en/university-college-utrecht/academics/internships .

The internship report must include an overview of the tasks completed during the internship which is to be verified by the host supervisor; a journal of activities, including summaries and conclusions of work-in-progress meetings.  The report should provide a contextualising introduction to the work undertaken; a description of that work; and a personal reflection connecting the work to the academic program. Any results of the tasks performed (for example written texts, interviews) should be included in the report as appendices. The student is responsible for completing the entire paperwork (Internship agreement and proposal signed by all parties involved) before submitting it to the college administration.1The deadline for submission can be found in the academic calendar.
The head/coordinator acts as an independent counsellor and may be consulted in case of problems in the course of the internship.
1. Name of the host institution, name host supervisor
3. Outline of envisioned tasks within the institution (50-100 words)
4. Indication of how the work will be carried out (50-100 words)
5. Indication of potential contribution to the institution (100-150 words)
6. Indication of how the practical work relates to the UCU curriculum (200-300 words)
7. timetable specifying the various stages of the internship, including the date for handing in the report

It is recommended that students carry out an internship in their second year at UCU, preferably during the summer break or during the winter break. Under certain circumstances, an internship may also be carried out as one of the courses taken during a regular semester.  Any such arrangements during the semester must be evaluated by the tutor in the context of the student’s total study plan.

The report must be handed in within 3 weeks after the internship ends, respecting the thesis deadline that can be found on the academic calendar. One copy must be submitted to the host institution; one to the UCU coordinator, and one to the Registrar. In addition, the student must submit an electronic version of the internship report, via Handin, to the Internships Workspace.
The final P/F grade is determined by the host institution supervisor and endorsed by the UCU coordinator.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/172309,2016,Internship Entrepreneurship & Innovation,English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,['drs. P.O. van der Meer'],,"Content

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
From academic knowledge to new value creation in professional practice

Utrecht University aims to be a research and teaching institution that contributes to the economy and society. In order to apply its expertise and develop its knowledge it is crucial to connect to businesses and other organisations. This internship enables students to gain experience in applying and developing academic knowledge in professional practice, to create new value and to discover future career opportunities. The internship thus provides the opportunity to experience how academic knowledge can be turned into new value. This internship can be done to complete the Minor Entrepreneurship (for non-economics students). The student is responsible for finding a hosting or supporting organisation and developing the internship proposal. The proposal should contain the activities that will be performed, information about the external supervisor, suggestions for the topic and approach, initial references to academic literature and a suggested planning.
After approval by the internship coordinator the student will be enrolled in Osiris.
For more information on business and entrepreneurship education: http://www.uu.nl/entrepreneurship and http://www.utrechtce.nl.
At the end of the course, the student:

column2: • Applied and developed his/her knowledge and skills in a professional practice;
• Developed his/her professional skills to do entrepreneurship-related work for the organisation that provides the internship opportunity;
• Is able to do an academic exploration of a problem encountered in practice

column1: Students are expected to spend at least two months full time at the organisation and complete an internship report.
A minimum of 90 ECTS is required, as well as some prior entrepreneurship and business education.

column2: • An assessment interview between the student and the internship coordinator, who safeguards the supervision of the internship on a contents based level;
• Three weeks after the working period has ended the student must hand in the internship portfolio to the internship coordinator.
• A copy of the form of approval of the internship;
• The assessment form completed by the external supervisor;
• A few examples of the work done by the student during the internship;
<li>A report of the internship period. The report should contain the following subjects:

column3: • A short description of the tasks realised and a self-assessment based on the assessment form;
• A short description of the organisation and the work area;
• A case description of the entrepreneurial issues that have been addressed.
• Plans and goals based on this work experience.

column2: • The student does or does not receive the credits based on the assessment of the content of the internship portfolio and the assessment interview with the internship coordinator.

column1: For information about schedule, enrollment, etc. please consult the Utrecht School of Economics Student Desk: http://students.uu.nl/en/leg/economics-and-business-economics.

column3: In het programma van de herziene master European Law is geen ruimte opgenomen voor een stage. Het is echter wel mogelijk om een stage te doen bovenop het reguliere programma. Hiervoor bestaan de volgende mogelijkheden:

Bij voorkeur doe je een stage nadat alle examenonderdelen van de opleiding zijn afgerond. Als je de stage na de opleiding doet, onderbreekt dat je masterprogramma niet, en je kunt dan tot je stage deel uit blijven maken van de community binnen de master en de reguliere momenten van begeleiding en feedback binnen het onderzoeks- en scriptietraject aanhouden. In dit geval vraag je na afronding van het scriptietraject uitstel van afstuderen aan bij de Examencommissie master. Deze mogelijkheid is als formele reden tot uitstel opgenomen in de onderwijs- en examenregeling en heeft geen gevolgen voor cijfers en beoordeling. Je kunt ook  tijdens de master  een onderzoeksstage volgen ten behoeve van je scriptie of een substantiële stage die niet op een ander moment gevolgd kan worden. In dat geval moet je ook voorafgaand aan de stage afspraken maken met de programmaleiding van de master over de geschiktheid van de stage, de tijdplanning en de van toepassing zijnde regels.

Je kunt ook een stage voor de start van de master volgen. Weliswaar is deze stage voor reguliere bachelorstudenten niet in hun bachelorprogramma in te brengen, maar de praktijk wijst uit dat de meeste studenten een stage volgen zonder deze in te brengen als keuzevak.</body>

column3: The internship consists of 10 full weeks of a work placement. It allows the student to experience a professional engagement within the MA study period. The internship is a central colomn within the study curriculum of the MA Gender Studies. Under supervision of a staff member (internal supervisor), the student is required to find his/her own internship by approaching organisations and companies of his/her interest. Before the internship starts, a workplan is developed together with the internship supervisor (internal and at the organization/institution) that specifies in detail the activities, projects, and the Gender Studies relevant research component of the internship. At the end of the internship the student will compile a report of both the achievements and experiences at the internship placement and present the undertaken research of the internship.</body>

column3: The research internship is designed to give students an opportunity to conduct a substantial, fieldwork-based individual research on a chosen topic related to international development and hence gain deeper understanding of development practices. Upon completion of the research internship, students should have acquired theoretical, methodological and practical competency that will be useful for their career in further academic research, development policy and practice sector, as well as other work fields that require analytical, communication and project implementation skills as well as cross-cultural competences.</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The majority of the students conduct a research internship in the Global South on a topic related to the core research themes presented in the Development Themes course. Students are given a broad choice of internships with broad research themes to students during the first period (around October). Students are expected to execute the research plan that they have drafted for Advanced Methods & Techniques for IDS course, and work under the supervision of their supervisor at IDS (and in close collaboration with the host organisations in the ‘field’, when applicable). Essential parts of this internship constitute a critical understanding of the main opportunities and challenges of specific development practice, the application of skills in research methodology and data analysis and the gaining of direct experience into the design and implementation of strategic interventions to tackle problems, including the potentials, limitations and constraints thereof. Drawing on their fieldwork findings, students write a policy-oriented research report upon their return from the ‘field’.

For those who so desire the University Library offers short (2-hour) guided search sessions. These will give you a head start in finding information. Staff will ensure that you do not miss out on any new important databases with journal articles and other information sources. For information and registration go to: http://www.uu.nl/university/library/en/disciplines/geo/courses/searchsessions/Pages/default.aspx
This course is the entry requirement for:

-          work in a project-based way and carry out relevant analyses for the product development task

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>In this course you’ll be working in an organization in the (in)formal science education field. You’ll experience this work environment, carry out all kinds of relevant tasks, seek active contact with the target audience(s) and meanwhile work on one main task: developing a product for your organization / supervisor that fits the wishes of the client. This product has to be finished and handed in together with a (research- or evidence-based) report on why and how the product was made. In addition you’ll have to reflect on your own learning process. Some Tuesdays in the first period there will be educational meetings on product development for (in)formal education and communication, while at the same time you work one day a week at the organization. In the second period you’ll work 30 – 40 hours in the organization – both to develop the product and to carry out other additional practical tasks. You’ll end this part of the course with a final product presentation, a written product report, and a reflection document.</body>

column3: Preparation for work in the field of literature. The student learns to apply the academic knowledge acquired in the course of the MA-program Literature Today to the work done in the internship-organization. </body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: The internship offers the student the opportunity to participate in real-life work processes in the field(s) relevant to the MA-program Literature Today. The internship is completed in national and international organizations active in the field of (production, dissimination, evaluation, teaching of) literature and culture. A substantial research component is part of an MA-internship, of which the findings are presented in the intership-report. column3: The general objective of the internship is to 'learn by doing' through engaging with professional practice in the field of CS&HR. Sub goals include: to set-up and apply a strategy to extract and gather data on a specific research theme; to articulate your position vis-à-vis your work environment; to critically assess and reflect upon your work environment by analyzing the assumptions about conflict (e.g. conflict causes, dynamics, prevention, or resolution) that underlie the activities/ policies of the workplace and relate this analysis to the theoretical discussions as reviewed in the taught courses of the MA programme and/or more broadly the literature on Conflict Studies and Human Rights; to articulate in writing what you learned from doing this internship that contributes to your skills and knowledge ‘mastery’ related to this Master’s in Conflict Studies & Human Rights. </body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174308,2016,Internship MA Contemporary Theatre, Dance and Dramaturgy",English,Faculty of Humanities,,"['dr. K.G. Georgelou', 'dr. L.W. Groot Nibbelink', 'dr. M.J. Kattenbelt', 'L.L. Karreman', 'prof. dr. M.A. Bleeker']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
The aim of the internship is to gain practical work experience and to develop reflection on professional practice, under the supervision both of a staff member of the organisation and one's tutor.
1. The internship (report) should reflect that the student has gained practical experience in his or her field of study and/or gained profound knowledge of a subset of the professional field.
2. The internship report (workfield evaluation component) should demonstrate that the student is able to develop reflection on professional practice and on personal learning goals.

3. The internship report (research component) should demonstrate that the student is able to research a specific topic within the context of the professional field, and to communicate insights to a wider audience, consisting of both academics as well as arts professionals.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The internship allows the student to gain hands on experience in a practice of his/her choice, either within the field of theatre and dance (dramaturgy, education, programming, publicity, policy, criticism) or in research about theatre and dance. An MA Internship consists of both a practical and an academically oriented component in which the student employs research and/or reflexive skills. Ideally, this research benefits both the internship organization and the MA Thesis.

During their internship, students participate in practical and/or research activities  and develop reflection about them. Prior to the internship they design a plan in which they define their goal and research questions. Afterwards, they reflect on the answers they have found to these questions in a written report.
This course can be followed either in combination with the MA Thesis throughout block 3 and 4 (lint option) or in block 4.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: An internship of at least three months offers you the opportunity to test your knowledge and skills in practice. Keep in mind that international organizations like the EU or the UN, or the Foreign Ministry of your country cannot offer a job to everyone with a MA degree in IR. However, with your skills in gathering reliable sources of information, and using these to write in-depth analyses on a variety of policy issues in an understandable language, you have the right profile to start a career as a policy maker with every organization and agency in the profit and non-profit sector. An internship in the world of international politics is great, but a policy internship with a multinational, a bank, or a consultancy agency can be rewarding and valuable as well. Of course you may also want to test your skills in the world of journalism. And if you opt for an academic career contact applied research agencies like Clingendael, Center for Terrorism and Counter Terrorism and the Insitute of Military History.
When having acquired an internship, please contact you MA coordinator who will assign you to an internship supervisor.

column4: Note: you must have at least 20 credits for the category M (Master) before starting your internship, obtained by completing the following courses:
GKMV16010 Ges-Modern world and states system (5 EC)
GKMV16012 Ges-Research seminar MA IR/HP (5 EC)
And two of the programme's electives:
GKMV16014 Ges-Military violence in IR (5 EC)

column2: • heeft de student zich georiënteerd op de beroepspraktijk van juristen;
• heeft de student geleerd om de in zijn studie opgedane kennis en vaardigheden toe te passen in de praktijk;
• heeft de student geleerd om onder tijdsdruk aan opdrachten te voldoen;

<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: In het programma van de herziene master Public International Law is geen ruimte opgenomen voor een stage. Het is echter wel mogelijk om een stage te doen bovenop het reguliere programma. Hiervoor bestaan de volgende mogelijkheden:

Bij voorkeur doe je een stage nadat alle examenonderdelen van de opleiding zijn afgerond. Als je de stage na de opleiding doet, onderbreekt dat je masterprogramma niet, en je kunt dan tot je stage deel uit blijven maken van de community binnen de master en de reguliere momenten van begeleiding en feedback binnen het onderzoeks- en scriptietraject aanhouden. In dit geval vraag je na afronding van het scriptietraject uitstel van afstuderen aan bij de Examencommissie master. Deze mogelijkheid is als formele reden tot uitstel opgenomen in de onderwijs- en examenregeling en heeft geen gevolgen voor cijfers en beoordeling. Je kunt ook  tijdens de master  een onderzoeksstage volgen ten behoeve van je scriptie of een substantiële stage die niet op een ander moment gevolgd kan worden. In dat geval moet je ook voorafgaand aan de stage afspraken maken met de programmaleiding van de master over de geschiktheid van de stage, de tijdplanning en de van toepassing zijnde regels.

Je kunt ook een stage voor de start van de master volgen. Weliswaar is deze stage voor reguliere bachelorstudenten niet in hun bachelorprogramma in te brengen, maar de praktijk wijst uit dat de meeste studenten een stage volgen zonder deze in te brengen als keuzevak.</body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/175010,2016,Internship RMA Comparative Literary Studies,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. F.D.G. de Glas', 'dr. F.R.W. Stolk', 'dr. O.R. Kosters']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: The student gains experience as a professional in the field of his/her MA programme in literary and cultural studies. The student learns how to apply the acquired knowledge of modern literary and cultural studies to institutions or companies in the aforementioned field on an academic working and thinking level. Additionally, the student learns how to test and evaluate his/her academic understanding of the field during the placement (to the extent they relate to each other).</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: The internship allows the student to orientate on possible professions and to participate in the labour market. During the internship, the student should apply knowledge and competences acquired during previous academic courses. The internship is preferably a placement at an institution or company outside of the department. Because it is a RMA internship, it should involve original research, to be reported in a research report. The actual activities of the internship should be described in the internship plan, which is to be written before the start of the internship. This plan should include a description of the internships’ objective; the student’s final product; a description of the learning objectives, and a description of the content and duration of the internship. When preparing for an internship, the student should get in touch with a tutor of his/her choice well in advance.
Note: only accessible to students that fit the specific entry requirements for this course’s MA programme.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174163,2016,Internship RMA Gender Studies,Dutch, English",Faculty of Humanities,,"['dr. C.L. Quinan', 'dr. D. Olivieri', 'dr. E. Midden', 'dr. K. Thiele', 'J. Mascat', 'L. Ftouni']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: After completion of the research internship, the student:
A) has learned to apply advanced academic research training in gender studies to a professional setting, both methodologically and theoretically
B) has developed an independent research focus for the internship, which is clearly outlined in the internship workplan and reflected upon in the final internship report
C) has used feminist methods in a practical/professional field
D) has learned to navigate professional networks within the field in Gender Studies.</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: The internship consists of 10 full weeks of a work/research placement. It allows the student to develop a professional research engagement within the RMA study program. Under supervision of a staff member (internal supervisor), the student reflects on their own research proposal to identify organisations and institutions where they could conduct research that matches their own interests and aims. Before the start of the internship, a workplan is developed together with the supervisors (internal and at the organization/institution) that specifies in detail the activities, projects, and gender-studies relevant research components of the internship. At the end of the internship, the student composes a report detailing the research findings and academic reflections of the internship placement as well as how it connects to the eventual thesis.

In constructing a concrete research project, the internship provides an opportunity for the student to function and to develop work- and research-related skills in the setting of a professional organisation. It provides students with the possibility to directly engage with the job market inside and outside of academia and enables them to establish a professional network.</body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174346,2016,Internship RMA Media, Art and Performance Studies","Dutch, English",Faculty of Humanities,,"['dr. M.J. Kattenbelt', 'dr. N. Verhoeff', 'prof. dr. M.A. Bleeker']",,"Course goals

body { font-size: 9pt; it has a length of about 30.000 words  and should not exceed 40.000 words (including notes and bibliography).
The individual thesis trajectory is supervised by a staff member of the program. The thesis will be evealuated by the supervisor and a second assessor appointed by the the programme coordinator.

column3: The internship consists of 10 full weeks of a work/research placement. It allows the student to develop a professional research engagement within the RMA study program. Under supervision of a staff member (internal supervisor), the student reflects on their own research proposal to identify organisations and institutions where they could conduct research that matches their own interests and aims. Before the start of the internship, a workplan is developed together with the supervisors (internal and at the organization/institution) that specifies in detail the activities, projects, and relevant research components of the internship. In constructing a concrete research project, the internship provides an opportunity for the student to function and to develop work- and research-related skills in the setting of a professional organisation. column3: In an internship you learn how to apply in practice the research skills that you acquired in earlier course work. An internship for a Research MA invariably includes a significant component of original research, such as cataloguing new or previously unresearched sources, helping develop new research techniques, or exploring cutting-edge methodologies, always under the guidance of an experienced supervisor. You also get to know the work environment of a research institute, research library, or scholarly archive. A successful internship not only functions as a crucial bridge to entering the work force but also provides you with the raw material for your MA thesis. </body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174960,2016,Internship Secondary Education,English,Faculty of Science,,['dr. A. Veldkamp', 'dr. ir. M.J. Vollebregt']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Upon completion of the course (11,25 EC) the student is able to

column5: Describe the teacher roles (SBL competences)  and is able to illustrate them properly using suitable examples
Analyse and describe some characteristics of learning processes in formal learning environments
Develop a lesson / an activity built upon theoretical notions
Name factors which can hamper / facilitate the implementation of a lesson / activity
Reflect upon the lesson / activity based upon the pre-set aims for the lesson / activity
Reflect upon personal growth and the differences between functioning in a school environment and designing materials there and designing educational material in an ‘outside school’ environment

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Whether you’re an informal or a formal educator in science and mathematics, you should always make your target audience the focus of your work. So in this course you’ll work closely with a specific target audience (secondary school pupils in formal education) and will get to know them through practical experience.

This course aims to bridge the gap between theory and practice: theoretical assumptions are continually applied and tested out in the formal educational setting. Additionally in a thematic curriculum theory and practice is integrated. Your own experiences at university and in your internship, are the focus of your learning and development. By reflecting upon those experiences and upon how you learn, you gradually develop insight in the variety of competencies required for teaching and learning.

During the course you’ll be in a school environment and will observe pupils and lessons in science education. You’ll gradually start to prepare and teach part of the lessons.The course will start with one full-time week at the institute to prepare for your school experience. Also the rest of the first period (period 3) you will join the students who are training to become a science / math teacher during their educational sessions at university. However you will work on your own, special tasks targeted at the development of competencies needed as a curriculum developer.
PLEASE NOTE: more information about schedules you can find at GSTDID1 and GSTMS1 for which you will be registered automatically.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/172950,2016,Internship Urban Geography,Dutch, English",Faculty of Geosciences,,['Docenten onderwijsinstituut SGPL'],,"Course goals

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: The student will be able to:

column5: Apply theoretical knowledge, research skills and professional skills, acquired during the Master's degree program, in a practical situation;
Function within an organisational structure and to take part in meetings;
Write a report on the performed internship activities;
Make a personal strengths/weaknesses analysis for future career planning.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column5: <div>

column6: Within the Master's degree program in Urban Geography, it is possible to - but not required - to do an internship with a maximum of 7.5 credits as part of the total 30 credits required for graduation. The aim of the internship is to acquire practical experience in a firm or (government) institution operating in the professional field of Urban Geography.

The internship gives a student the opportunity to reflect on acquired knowledge from a practical perspective, to further develop knowledge and skills, to reconsider beliefs and to explore personal positions within the professional field. The nature and level of internship activities have to be consistent with knowledge and skills acquired during the Master's degree program. Considering the limited scope of the internship, it is strongly recommended - should an internship be desired - to combine the internship and the Master thesis. Students who prefer to do an internship need to contact the coordinator of the master programme in Urban Geography. Students should in principle find an internship themselves, in cooperation with the Urban Geography staff. Because the internship needs to fit the subject matter of the Master program in Urban Geography, it is necessary to get an internship proposal officially approved by the Master coordinator before commencing the internship.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/173413,2016,Internship and Labourmarket Preparation,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['drs. S.B. Soeparman', 'prof. dr. ir. A.G. van der Lippe']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: The internship will enable students to:

column5: Gather empirical data for the masterthesis
Link academic theory to practice
Apply knowledge, skills and experience to a work environment
Demonstrate professional skills in the workplace
Build and maintain positive professional relationships
Demonstrate awareness of issues that are specific to a certain policy field, institutional environment or organization
Develop self-understanding, self-discipline, reflective capabilities, maturity and confidence
Develop strong networking/mentoring relationships within a professional and potential future work environment.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Together, the internship and labour market preparation (course code 201600012) and the Master's thesis (course code 201600013) form a whole and are worth a total of 30 credits.

The internship is designed to receive experience in applying theories learned in the curriculum to specific professional contexts.The internship will heighten students awareness of  issues that are specific to a certain professional environment or policy field. The internship is an opportunity to not only use and develop knowledge and skills that are specific to the internship organization, but also to enhance some of the skills that are transferable to any professional work setting. The internship can give you valuable information in making decisions about the direction of future studies or employment.

In principle, the internship and policy research will take place in combination. This can only be waived in exceptional cases. Agreement about the policy research to be undertaken will take place at the beginning of the internship and a suitable supervisor will be assigned. A project plan and a strict timetable will be discussed with the assigned supervisor.
During the internship students are expected to gather empirical data with which to write their master thesis.
Completing the Masters programme in Sociology: contemporary social problems provides students with:
Knowledge and understanding in the area of defining problems, theories, research and policy:
1c            Scientific and field practice developments within a social sector or organisation.
1d           The key characteristics of different domain-specific areas and problem contexts.
2a           Analyse complex questions from a sociological/interdisciplinary/comparative theoretical perspective and relate these to scientific and social debates.
2b           Translate/apply new and previously acquired socio-scientific knowledge to current social issues.
2e           Carry out independent research, draw conclusions from it in written and spoken form in a clear, straightforward manner to present to an audience of specialists and non-specialists.
2f            Create a link between scientific knowledge, research questions and practical issues.
2g           Provide a client with responsible advice on policy or organisation.
Form judgements about scientific­, societal and ethical aspects.

3a           Reflect on developments and discussions in science and society with regard to current social issues, on the basis of well-founded theoretical, analytical, methodological and practice-oriented considerations.
3b           Critically reflect upon information they have gathered themselves on current social issues based on theoretical, methodological, practice-oriented and social considerations.
3c            Adopt an honest and critical position in relation to research plans and results.
3e           Think critically about the professional ethics of people working in sociology within a wide social context.
3f            Think critically about the professional ethics of actors in the future professional field.

3g           Make a sound assessment of the scientific quality of proposed measures and of the organisational, political and administrative and social practicality of the policy and organisation advice formulated.
4a           Report, independently and in an academically sound way, on their own activities and present clear recommendations to interested parties both verbally and in writing.
4b           Skilful communication and interaction with colleagues and others working in the future professional field.
4c            Report the results of their own research, or advice, to clients or others working in the field verbally and in writing in a clear and structured manner.
4d           Critique and comment on reports by fellow students, others working in the field, colleagues and clients in a constructive manner.
5a           Reflect on the development of their professional identity and take action on this by developing their own competencies (lifelong learning).
5b           Reflect upon professional ethical issues within their future professional field.
5c            Deal with ethical aspects in a well-considered manner as an academic professional.
5d           Be part of the social context, taking into account the parties concerned and thus deal with them with integrity and in a scientific and professional manner.
5f            Collaborate with professionals from other scientific disciplines.

column3: Dutch students in the RMA Art History do their internship (or placement) abroad, while students from elsewhere find a place in one of the major Dutch or Flemish institutions. Most Dutch students go to the U.K., Germany or Ireland, although some have reached out as far as Japan. In the Netherlands, most students from abroad do their internship in the Rijksmuseum, Museum Boijmans Van Beuningen, and the Stedelijk Museum Amsterdam. In Flanders, the museums in Bruges offer good opportunities.As an alternative, students can take research seminars or tutorials at an advanced level at other universities in Europe or the US. The alternative has to be approved by the programme coordinator.</body>

column5: After completing the internship, students will have:

column4: The internship report is the most important assessment of the students' academic, professional and personal development, in which they describe their experiences with and reflections on the internship. The level of academic, ethical, professional and personal reflection demonstrated in the report is a key element of the assessment. The internship report will be assessed by the lecturer responsible for internships and an independent second assessor, after the internship supervisor from the organisation has checked the validity of the statements therein. The student's professional development is guided by means of peer review and supervision meetings, interim and final evaluations. In the internship supervisor's final evaluation, the supervisor provides a recommended mark that helps to determine the final mark. Students are primarily responsible for their own professional development, assisted by contributions from fellow students, the lecturer and the internship supervisor. In the internship report, students demonstrate their ability to provide a concise and reflective description of their activities during the internship and their resulting professional development.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: Students are primarily responsible for finding and being accepted by a suitable internship organisation. The Clinical and Health Psychology department maintains a database of internship organisations that are part of its regular network. However, students are also expected to actively search for an internship placement that meets the set requirements. New placements must first be approved by the internship coordinator.

The internship is a study component in which students do an active professional internship in the field of clinical psychology. During the internship, students learn to integrate theory, empirical knowledge, methodologies and their other academic skills into professional practice. It is important for Master's students to learn to reflect on their academic, professional and personal qualities. As a future professional, students are expected to demonstrate considerable self-management skills and be clearly oriented towards the job market. Students in the Clinical Psychology track will do their internship at an organisation for basic and specialised mental healthcare (including the medical psychology and rehabilitation departments). The Clinical Psychology track offers the opportunity to do either a clinical internship or a research internship related to mental healthcare. Work performed on a clinical internship can include diagnostics, treatment or needs assessment. During the internship, students will practice professional skills in these fields and, in doing so, start to develop a professional and academic attitude. Students are generally supervised by a healthcare psychologist or an experienced academic psychologist within the organisation. The clinical internship also prepares students for a healthcare psychologist or psychotherapist post-Master's programme. Pay careful attention to the previous education requirements for both programmes: see http://www.rinogroep.nl. The clinical psychology research internship is intended for students wishing to familiarise themselves with research-related activities. Students actively participate in an ongoing mental healthcare-related research project at an organisation, gaining experience with professional and academic skills connected to different phases of the empirical cycle, such as literature review, data collection, data analysis and reporting research results. Students are supervised by an experienced academic professional within the organisation.

column4: The internship is a study component in which students do an active professional internship in the field of clinical psychology or health promotion. During the internship, students learn to integrate theory, empirical knowledge, methodologies and their other academic skills into professional practice. It is important for Master's students to learn to reflect on their academic, professional and personal qualities. As a future professional, students are expected to demonstrate considerable self-management skills and be clearly oriented towards the job market. Students in the Health Promotion track will do their internship at an organisation in the field of promoting good health, such as the Netherlands National Institute for Public Health and the Environment (Rijksinstituut voor Volksgezondheid en Milieu, RIVM, the Netherlands Nutrition Centre, the local Community Health Service (Gemeentelijke Gezondheidsdienst, GGD) or first-line basic healthcare institutions (e.g. general practitioners).

column3: The Health Promotion track offers the opportunity to do either a practical internship or a research internship. During a practical internship, students gain experience with prevention, treatment or policymaking activities within health promotion or clinical psychology. Such activities consist of participating in providing information, training, and interventions in the field of health promotion and preventive measures. Students thereby gain experience using psychological strategies in the field of preventive measures and behavioural changes, as well as with designing, implementing and evaluating interventions for promoting good health. The research internship is intended for students wishing to familiarise themselves explicitly with research-related activities. Students actively participate in an ongoing health promotion-related research project at an organisation, gaining experience with professional and academic skills connected to different phases of the empirical cycle, such as literature review, data collection, data analysis and reporting research results. Students are supervised by an experienced academic professional within the organisation.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Aan het eind van de cursus:

column5: ben je in staat om interpersoonlijke processen te benoemen en te duiden volgens het begrippenkader van de interpersoonlijke theorie;
ben je je bewust van het interpersoonlijk effect van je eigen gedrag in de klas;
kun je eigen gedrag en dat van anderen analyseren en gedragsalternatieven formuleren;
heb je je gedragsrepertoire uitgebreid.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Wat er in de klas gebeurt kan vanuit verschillende oogpunten worden beschreven, bijvoorbeeld:

Welke kennis komt aan bod? Welke leeractiviteiten? Maar ook: wat gebeurt er interpersoonlijk tussen docent en leerlingen? Interpersoonlijke processen in de klas hangen aan de ene kant samen met leeropbrengsten van leerlingen (hoe goed presteren leerlingen, maar ook hoe leuk vinden leerlingen een vak) en aan de andere kant met opbrengsten van docenten. Hoeveel stress ervaren docenten en hoe gemotiveerd zijn zij voor hun berope? Basisbeginsel van het interpersoonlijke perspectief is dat een klas een sociaal systeem is, waarin docent en leerlingen elkaars gedrag wederzijds beïnvloeden en dat al het gedrag dat een docent in de klas vertoont een interpersoonlijke betekenis heeft. Deze betekenis beschrijven we met de mate van invloed van een docent (d.w.z. dominantie of sturing) en de mate van nabijheid (de warmte in het contact met leerlingen).
In dit keuzevak wordt een begrippenkader aangereikt waarmee interpersoonlijke aspecten van lesgeven, zoals relaties met leerlingen en interactie in de klas kunnen worden beschreven.
Studenten leren de wetmatigheden van interpersoonlijke processen kennen en leren hun gedrag als instrument in de klas in te zetten. We leggen uit waarom je wél moet 'lachen voor de kerst'.
NB: Voor deelname aan deze cursus is het noodzakelijk dat je gedurende de cursusperiode toegang hebt tot een vo-klas (als stagiair of docent)!

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/170913,2016,Interpersonal and institutional communication,Dutch,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. J.C. Bos', 'prof. dr. C.H.C.J. van Nijnatten']",,"Course goals
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Inzicht in enkele sociaalwetenschappelijke theorieën over         interpersoonlijke         en         institutionele         communicatie
Kennis en toepassing van methoden van interactie-onderzoek         (discourseanalyse,         conversatieanalyse)

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Communicatie is een belangrijk thema in het wetenschappelijk onderzoek naar het functioneren van mensen. (Verbale) interacties spelen een belangrijke rol in de ontwikkeling van psychologische functies, bij instructie van (jonge) mensen en het overbrengen van belangrijke kennis en informatie op diverse terreinen. Communicatie vindt plaats tussen personen in 'normale' dagelijkse situaties en in situaties waarin een bijzonder institutioneel doel in het spel is (bijvoorbeeld bij de reactie op een hulpvraag van een patiënt, een rapportbespreking met ouders, een rechtszaak).

In de cursus staan twee klassieke sociaalwetenschappelijk theorieën over sociale interactie tussen mensen centraal: Goffman en Watzlawick. De theorie wordt behandeld in hoorcolleges, werkgroepen + responsie en plenaire besprekingen van beroemde speelfilms. Hierna wordt aan de hand van de gepresenteerde theorieën ingegaan op interactie-analytische toepassingen (conversatie-analyse en discoursanalyse). De cursus gaat niet alleen over interactie-analyse, maar probeert ook interactief te zijn in haar werkwijze. Studenten passen bovenstaande wetenschappelijke inzichten toe in opdrachten die in werkgroepverband worden uitgevoerd. .</body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/171021,2016,Interpersonal processes,Dutch,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['Docenten van de afdeling/departement(en)', 'dr. R.C. van der Wal']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Gaining knowledge of the most important theories and empirical research on interpersonal processes. Conducting a literature search on a specific theme within the domain of interpersonal processes. Applying social psychological theories on a societal problem and developing interventions from a social psychological perspective. Gaining knowledge of and insight in conflict management.</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column5: <div>

column11: In deze cursus worden interpersoonlijke processen, in het bijzonder interpersoonlijke relaties en gedrag, behandeld vanuit een sociaal-psychologisch perspectief. De nadruk ligt op theorieën en onderzoek op het gebied van partnerrelaties, maar er zal ook aandacht besteed worden aan andere interpersoonlijke relaties zoals vriendschapsrelaties, gezinsrelaties en werkrelaties. Tijdens de cursus wordt een overzicht gegeven van de belangrijkste interpersoonlijke processen en fenomenen en de theorieën en het empirisch onderzoek op dit terrein. Belangrijke onderwerpen die aan bod komen zijn attractie en affiliatie, sociale cognities in relaties, communicatie en interactie, sociale uitwisseling en interdependentie, rechtvaardigheid, macht en conflicthantering, mediation, onderhandelen, attachment, commitment en tevredenheid.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: Voorbereidend op de afstudeerfase wordt binnen deze cursus aandacht besteed aan een aantal aspecten rondom het opzetten van wetenschappelijk onderzoek, met aandacht voor implementatie van de resultaten in de klinische praktijk, resultaten van wetenschappelijk onderzoek te interpreteren en overtuigend te communiceren over onderzoeksplannen, opzet en resultaten.

Er wordt aan de hand van een bestaande recente dataset aandacht besteed aan datamanagement, -analyse en –interpretatie. Daarnaast komt de systematiek rondom implementatie aan de orde, hierbij wordt gebruik gemaakt van implementatieprojecten uit de dagelijkse praktijk van het Koninklijk Genootschap voor Fysiotherapie (KNGF). Tot slot wordt aandacht besteed aan opinievorming en kritisch reflecteren op maatschappelijk relevante thema’s in de vorm van een debat.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174493,2016,Interreligious Relations: Islam and Christianity,Dutch,Faculty of Humanities,,[],,Course goals
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
·        Heeft de student kennis van en inzicht in de geschiedenisvan relaties tussen Moslims en Christenen in Europa;
·        Heeft de student een theoretisch-analytisch kader om verschillende vormen van interreligieuze relaties te duiden
·        Kan de student actuele interreligieuze verhoudingen tussen Islam en Christendom interpreteren vanuit historische ontwikkelingen
·        Heeft de student inzicht in actuele moeilijkheden en mogelijkheden van interreligieuze relaties tussen Islam en Christendom;
·        Heeft de student kennis gemaakt met de praktijk van interreligieuze dialoog in Nederland
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Het eerste deel van de cursus behandelt de verhoudingen tussen christendom en islam in historisch perspectief, met een focus op Europa. Daarbij besteden we  aandacht aan de geschiedenis van de beeldvorming tussen beide religies. Het tweede deel van de cursus behandelt actuele thema's in de relaties tussen beide godsdiensten, zoals de impact van de clash of civilizations-these op interreligieuze beeldvorming en initiatieven in interreligieuze dialoog, het Nederlandse Islamdebat. Het derde deel van de cursus gaat in op de hedendaagse praktijk van de interreligieuze dialoog in Nederland.
